issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int) (problem_statement.md lines 26-31). However, the provided solution (and the template Main usage) implement and expect a single-parameter constructor (Animal(String)) and only a name attribute (see solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java lines 6-8 and template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Main.java lines 9-11). This mismatch between the specified constructor signature in the UML and the constructor used in template/solution will confuse students about which constructor they must implement and whether an age attribute is required.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the constructor-signature mismatch by choosing one of two consistent options: (A) Update the problem statement (UML and text) to declare Animal with only the name attribute and a constructor Animal(String) so it matches the template usage and the solution; or (B) Update the template and solution to include the age attribute and change all constructors to accept (String name, int age), and update Main and any example code accordingly. Either choice is fine pedagogically, but they must be consistent across problem statement, template, and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML and text indicate Animal has an 'age: int' attribute (problem_statement.md lines 26-29). The solution implementation of Animal, however, only declares a 'name' attribute and omits 'age' entirely (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java lines 3-8). This is an attribute-level inconsistency: students will be unsure whether they must add and manage an age field (with getter/setter) as requested in the UML and task description.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute list consistent across artifacts. Either (A) remove 'age' from the UML and problem text if the exercise does not require it (and explicitly state that only 'name' is required), or (B) add the 'age' field to the template and solution Animal class (private int age), include corresponding getter/setter, and ensure all concrete subclasses and example usage (Main) construct Animals with both name and age. Document the chosen design clearly in the problem statement so students know which attributes to implement.
